definitionA: a person, especially an orator or political leader, who gains power and popularity by arousing the emotions, passions, and prejudices of the people.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A political orator or leader who gains favor by pandering to or exciting the passions and prejudices of the audience rather than by using rational argument.
   2. A leader of the people.
<verb>
   1. To speak or act in the manner of a demagogue; to speak about (an issue) in the manner of a demagogue.
etymology: 1640–50; < Greek dēmagōgós a leader of the people, popular leader, equivalent to dêm ( os ) people + agōgós leading, guiding; -agogue
example: Trump, like other autocrats and demagogues, knows that he must always appear to be doing something, a man of action and destiny, to keep and expand his base of support.

definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Unfamiliar, strange, foreign.
   2. Clumsy, awkward.
   3. Unrefined, crude.
etymology: before 900; Middle English; Old English uncūth ( un- 1, couth 2 ); cognate with Dutch onkond
example: It was classic Alatorre: uncompromising, uncouth and unapologetic in the name of exerting his influence to better Latinos.

definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The action of ruffling or setting in disorder.
<verb>
   1. To put into disorder; to tumble; to touse; to muss.
etymology: 1400–50; late Middle English touselen (v.); cognate with Low German tūseln. See touse, -le
example: "You tousle its mane and pull its ears, but all the time you’re thinking, those claws, those claws, those claws."

etymology: 1250–1300; Middle English -t ( o ) usen, in betusen, fortusen to handle roughly (simple verb first recorded in the early 16th century); cognate with Old Frisian tūsen to rend, German zausen to tousle
example: Researchers have previously found that when people recycle, they feel entitled touse more resources and produce more waste.

definitionA: to struggle or fight roughly or vigorously; wrestle; scuffle.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A physical fight or struggle.
   2. A conflict, an argument, a disagreement.
<verb>
   1. To have a tussle.
etymology: 1425–75; late Middle English (north and Scots ) tusillen, derivative ( -le ) of tusen to touse
example: Yet in their latest tussle with a German giant, Celtic emerged defeated 2-1, but "not broken" in the words of manager Brendan Rodgers.

definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A long and complicated procedure that seems tiresome or pointless.
   2. Nonsense; confused and incoherent talk.
<adjective>
   1. Prolix; tedious.
etymology: First recorded in 1730–40; alteration of ragman roll
example: Even though she wants to stay informed, Fox said, she has taken a step back from keeping up with the daily rigmarole of politics.

definitionA: a clever or witty remark or comment.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A smart, sarcastic turn or jest; a taunt; a severe retort or comeback; a gibe.
<verb>
   1. To make a quip.
   2. To taunt; to treat with quips.
etymology: 1525–35; back formation from quippy quip < Latin quippe indeed
example: Responsible media coverage of these encounters must go beyond a Dr. Phil quip.

definitionA: a person who gathers or deals in rag.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A person who collects and sells unwanted household items such as rags and other refuse for a living, a rag and bone man.
<noun>
   1. A statute issued by Edward I in 1276.
   2. A document having many names or seals, such as a papal bull.
   3. A game in which players compete to pull an object from out of a roll of writing.
example: That front-page story in The Times, from July 1905, had to do with a race riot that broke out when a Black man stepped in to assist a local ragman who needed help making his way through the neighborhood.

definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A small argument; a petty quarrel.
   2. Liquor; especially, a small draught of liquor.
<verb>
   1. To quarrel.
<verb>
   1. To deck out; to dress.
<verb>
   1. (British India) To have lunch.
example: Her tiffs with Harry are less about her transition and more about the kind of differences a father and daughter would have after they’ve been estranged for decades.

definitionA: being more than is sufficient or required; excessive.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. In excess of what is required or sufficient.
etymology: irst recorded in 1400–50; late Middle English, from Latin superfluus, from super- super- + flu- (stem of fluere “to flow”) + -us -ous
example: Republicans argue that the costs are superfluous, part of bloated spending of taxpayer funds that President Trump has appointed Elon Musk to pare down.
